You get rolling farmland, forest roads, and a genuine community vibe without the crowds or hype of bigger events. The course is challenging enough to be interesting but accessible enough for most riders. It's volunteer-run, affordable, and has that authentic small-race feel where everyone knows each other by the end.

logistics.explanation: The race starts at Back Forty Artisan Cheese Farm on 1406 Gulley Road, but rider navigation issues plagued the 2025 event. Douglas Van Den Ham went off course and completed 79km instead of the full Epic distance, highlighting course marking deficiencies.

length.explanation: The Epic Course (108.5 km) produces competitive racing, with Michael Joannisse winning in 3:13:32 and the top 8 men finishing within 4:32 of each other. Three distance options accommodate different abilities, from 35km to the full Epic distance that tests endurance without requiring multi-day recovery. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Single lane treed gravel roads through challenging sections at Ranger Camp, North Shore, and Clarendon test bike handling skills. The marble-white roads from nearby Tatlock Quarry create a Strada Bianche aesthetic but don't demand advanced technical abilities beyond standard gravel competency. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: Rolling hills through North Frontenac and Lanark Highlands create steady climbing rather than explosive ascents. The terrain features enough elevation to separate the field - Jennifer Stephenson's 26.47 km/h winning pace in the women's Epic shows the hills demand respect without approaching mountain territory. Less climbing than The Mid South.

altitude.explanation: Mississippi Station sits in the Canadian Shield near sea level. Altitude plays no role whatsoever in this race - the challenge comes entirely from distance and terrain, not thin air. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds ‚Äî no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Old logging roads wind through forests with views of Dalhousie Lake, taking riders through terrain where "maple syrup is the most abundant natural resource." The single lane treed roads offer countryside exploration, though the adventure stays within civilized rural Ontario rather than wilderness territory.

prestige.explanation: As a "marquee event" in the Gravel Cup Canada series, it draws regional attention but lacks international recognition. Organized by Brendan Gorman, the race accommodated 112 participants in 2025, making it a solid provincial fixture rather than a destination event.

race_quality.explanation: Navigation issues affected the 2025 event, with Douglas Van Den Ham going off course and completing only 79km. Staggered starts by distance (Epic at 9:00am, Medio at 9:30am, Petit at 9:45am) show organized planning, though course marking needs improvement to prevent rider errors.

experience.explanation: Riders finish at Back Forty Artisan Cheese Farm's "picturesque location" on the Mississippi River shore with "calming distant sound of waterfalls." Post-race, participants "relax and reminisce with food and drink" while being "spellbound by views" of the natural landscape.

community.explanation: The venue earns praise for its "gorgeous venue and delicious post-ride meals" at the artisan cheese farm. Even with "not ideal" weather in 2024, participants "managed to have an amazing time," showing the community spirit that sustains this rural Ontario gathering.

field_depth.explanation: The Epic Course men's field spread from Michael Joannisse's winning 3:13:32 to finish times over 6:47:49, indicating primarily recreational participation. With 36 starters and 5 DNFs in the men's Epic, competitive depth remains limited to regional riders. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: Three distance options let riders choose their challenge level, while the post-race experience at an artisan cheese farm by the Mississippi River with waterfalls delivers memorable value. The scenic venue and quality post-ride meals likely exceed typical entry fee expectations for Canadian gravel racing.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $50-80 CAD. Rural Mississippi Station, Ontario offers affordable lodging and dining options far from tourist pricing. The remote location requires driving but keeps accommodation costs low, with the biggest expense being the artisan cheese farm venue that enhances rather than gouges the race experience. More affordable than Crusher in the Tushar.

my only child. I listened to him
rehearse the lies that would strip me of
my home, my autonomy, my name. The same
voice that once shouted, "Dad, I can
hear the whole world was now being tuned
and sculpted to destroy mine." I had
expected Deanna's cruelty. She was a
predator. Predators hunt. It is what
they do. But this sound, the sound of my
son's surrender, the flat obedience in
his voice as he said, "Okay," was a
frequency of grief I had never known. He
wasn't evil. He was captured. He was a
signal buried so deep in noise that he
no longer remembered his own sound. And
in 2 weeks, he was going to walk into a
courtroom and perform a script written
by his captor. And he was going to
believe he was helping me. The question
was no longer whether I could win. I had
the evidence. I had the recordings. I
knew I could win. The real question was
what would be left of my son when I did.
Later that night, I drove to a gas
station on the edge of town. I stood by
the air pump under the buzzing
fluorescent lights and called Arlo. She
is coaching him, I said. I have the
recording. That is good evidence. Norm
Marlo said. That is dynamite. That is my
son, Arlo.
There was a long silence on the line. I
could hear the wind whistling past the
phone. I know. Arlo said finally. His
voice was heavy. That is why we have to
win. Sleep was a country I could no
longer visit. I sat on the edge of my
bed in the 2 a.m. darkness of the
garage. The house was a dead frequency
zone. The only sound, the low 120 hertz
hum of the furnace kicking on in the
basement. I had no equipment on, no
headphones, no recorder running. There
was nothing left to capture but the
static inside my own head. I kept
playing the last recording, not Deanna's
voice. I was immune to that now. It was
Brett's the flat rehearsed monotone as
he recited the word she had fed him. The
sound of his surrender. The way he said
okay when she told him this was for the
best. That was the sound that was
breaking me. For 5 weeks I had been the
hero of my own story. The quiet man
fighting back. The sound engineer
building a case. But what if I was just
another kind of liar? I had been
recording my family in secret. I had
been performing the role of a confused
old man. I was manipulating perception
just like she was. Only my tools were
microphones and equalizers instead of
fake concern and gaslighting. I was
building a weapon to destroy my son's
life to save my own. Even if I won, what
would Brett become? The man who finds
out his wife is a predator who tried to
kill his father. The son who sat in a
courtroom and testified against that
same father only to be proven a fool.
Either way, he was destroyed. The
foundation of his life would turn to
dust. Maybe the best thing to do was to
just let it go. I could pack a bag. I
could walk out the door before the sun
came up. I could find a small apartment
on the other side of town. Let Deanna
have the house. Let her have the money.
It was just paper. It was just wood and
nails. In time, maybe Brett and I could
find our way back to each other. Maybe
if I sacrificed everything, I could
salvage that one last thing. I picked up
my phone. The screen cast a cold blue
light on my hands. I looked at Arlo's
number. I could call him, tell him to
drop the counter petition. I could tell
him I was done. My thumb hovered over
the call button. I couldn't do it. I
swiped over to my photos instead. I
found the picture that lived on the
refrigerator door. Brett, age 8, sitting
on my lap in the main studio at WLFI. He
was wearing my huge headphones, his eyes
wide with wonder, a gap to smile on his
face. The memory was so clear, I could
smell the ozone from the tape machines.
Dela, I whispered into the darkness.
What would you do? You always heard me
even when I wasn't speaking. I need to
hear you now. The silence that answered
was absolute. It was the loneliest
frequency of all. My hand moved on its
own. It reached for the old Sony
cassette player on my nightstand. I
picked it up. The plastic was cool,
worn, smooth from years of use. It felt
like a part of my own body. I pressed
the eject button. The door opened with a
soft mechanical sigh. I took out the
tape. Dela's tape, the one I hadn't
listened to since the heart attack. I
had been afraid to. I was afraid that
hearing her voice so full of life would
shatter the cold professional shell I
had built around myself. But it was 2:30
in the morning, and the shell was
already cracking. I put the tape back in
and pressed play. The familiar click and
wor of the mechanism was a sound from
another lifetime. Then the hiss of
magnetic particles rushing past a
playhead. Her voice filled the small
room singing that old Roy Orbison song.
Blue Bayou slightly off key, full of
sunlight and pancake batter. The
recording was full of life, the clatter
of a fork, the hiss of the gas stove,
the shuffle of her slippers on the
lenolium floor. It was the sound of a
woman who didn't know she was being
preserved for a future she would never
see.
My chest achd with a grief so sharp it
felt like the heart attack was starting
all over again. The song finished. There
were 10 seconds of silence. Then the
sound of her humming something else too
quiet to identify. And then another
voice. Brett. He was 22 home from
college for the weekend. His voice was
higher than clearer, not yet thickened
with the compromises of adult life. Mom,
you sound so happy. He said on the tape.
Dela laughed. a sound like windchimes.
"I am happy, baby," she answered. "Your
father gave me the best gift this
morning." "What was that?" Brett asked.
Dela's recorded voice spoke the words
that changed everything. He listened to
me. "Really listened? Do you know how
rare that is?" "A man who actually hears
you?" The tape hissed for a few more
seconds and then the recording ended. I
sat in the dark. The words echoed in the
silence of the garage. "A man who
actually hears you." That was what she
valued. Not my paycheck from the
station, not the promotions I never got.
She valued the one thing I knew how to
do better than anyone else. I knew how
to listen. And in that moment, sitting
in a cold garage with a laptop full of
lies and a broken heart. I finally
understood what I had to do. This wasn't
about destroying Deanna. This wasn't
about revenge. This was about making
Brett here. Not my words, not my
accusations. I had to make him hear the
truth in the one voice he might still
believe hers. I wasn't a lawyer. I
wasn't a fighter. I was a sound
engineer. My entire life, my one job had
been to take a messy, noisy, complicated
signal and make it clean. To make the
important voices clear so the audience
could hear what mattered. I had one more
show to produce. I sat up straight. I
wiped my face on the sleeve of my shirt.
I turned on my laptop. The screen
glowed. I opened the audio files, all 23
of them. I started dragging them into
the editing software, lining them up on
the timeline. I wasn't just collecting
evidence anymore. I was building a
narrative. I was crafting a broadcast.
This one wasn't for the radio. This one
was for an audience of one. A son who
needed to hear his wife's real voice for
the first time. And a judge who was
going to be sitting in the front row. At
6:00 in the morning, as the first gray
light began to filter through the garage
window, I called Willa. "I need your
studio," I said. "Today all day," her
voice was thick with sleep, but she
didn't hesitate. "What are we building?"
"A broadcast," I said. "The last one of
my career." "I will make the coffee,"
she said and hung up. For the next week,
Willa's studio became my entire world.
We worked in long, silent shifts fueled
by black coffee and a shared unspoken
rage. I sat at the mixing console, my
hands moving over the sliders and knobs
with an intimacy born of 40 years of
practice. This was my craft. This was my
church. I took Deanna's voice and I put
it under a microscope. I surgically
removed the sound of Brett snoring. I
used a DSER to soften the harsh
sibilance of her lies. I used a noise
gate to create stark dramatic silences
between her sentences. I took every
recording where she said the word
honestly and edited them together into a
brutal percussive super cut. Honestly,
honestly, honestly. Each one a hammer
blow. Willow worked on the visuals. She
took my phone pictures and cleaned them
up. She blew up the image of the
guardianship petition, highlighting the
date in red. She found a clear, smiling
photo of Earl Langston from an old
church directory and placed it side by
side with his obituary. Arlo came by on
the final day. He watched the full
12-minute presentation on the studio
monitor without a word. When it was
over, he just nodded. "That will do," he
said. We rendered the final file, a
single video file on a thumb drive, 12
minutes long, the length of a radio news
segment. It was the story of a man being
erased. And it was told entirely in the
voice of the woman holding the eraser.
The work was done. The broadcast was
ready. All that was left was to find a
stage. The morning of the hearing, I
woke up on Will's sofa. The apartment
smelled of coffee and newsprint. For a
moment, I didn't know where I was. Then
the weight of the day settled on me, a
physical pressure in my chest. Willa had
made breakfast eggs and toast, but I
couldn't eat. The food sat on the plate
like a prop. I drank the coffee black
and bitter. I stood in front of the
mirror in her small bathroom and
straightened the knot of my tie. I was
wearing the suit Dela had bought me for
our 40th anniversary, dark navy wool. I
had only worn it once to her funeral.
The faint scent of mothballs clung to
the fabric, a smell like preserved time.
I took the hearing aids from their case.
I picked them up. The small plastic
shells cool against my fingertips. I
settled them in my ears. A familiar
routine. The world snapped into focus.
The hiss of the radiator, the distant
groan of a garbage truck. Then, with a
slow, deliberate press of my thumb, I
turned them both off. I didn't need
amplification today. Today, the world
was going to hear me. Will drove. The
car was quiet as we crossed the Wobbash
River. The water a sheet of dull gray
steel under the February sky. "You
ready, Norm?" she asked, not taking her
eyes off the road. "40 years of sound
checks," I said. "One more." She glanced
at me, a quick fierce look. Dela would
be so proud. I looked out the window at
the flat frozen fields of Indiana. She
would be furious, I said, then proud in
that order. The courtroom was exactly as
I remembered it from my flash forward.
It was the same stage, but the actors
were different now. I was different. The
fluorescent lights still hummed at 60
hertz. Deanna still wore the navy
blazer, the tag still tucked inside the
collar. Brett still sat beside her in
his Ford polo shirt. Deanna's lawyer
went first. He painted a picture of a
loving daughter-in-law burdened by a
confused, declining father. He used
words like erratic and incapable. He
spoke of my self- neglect that led to
the heart attack. Then he called his
only witness, Brett Puit. My son made
the slow walk to the witness box. He
moved like a man walking through deep
water. His hand, when he placed it on
the Bible, was trembling. He sat down.
He put his hands in his pockets, hiding
them from view. He began to speak. The
words came out flat, hollow, devoid of
any frequency that sounded like my son.
He was a playback machine reciting a
corrupted file. My father has shown

months. He set his eyes fixed on a point
on the far wall. He wanders the house at
night. He recited the lies she had
written for him. Word for word, he told
the court that I forgot my medication.
He told them I talked to recordings of
my dead wife. And then he delivered the
final polished line. His heart attack
was sadly a result of his own
negligence. I watched him. I did not
flinch. I didn't look away. I just

Mr. Puit, he asked, "Who wrote those

"I see." Arlo said. "We will revisit

from 12 feet away in an open plan

shared living space during every
recording. Indiana code 35-33.5-5-5
one party consent. Every recording was
legally obtained. He is crazy, Deanna
screamed. He is a crazy old man who Mrs.
Puit Judge Frick's voice cut through the
air like a blade. Sit down. Deanna
didn't sit. She spun around and faced
Brett, her face contorted. Her final
desperate instinct was to attack. Brett,
tell them. Tell them your father is
confused. Tell them I was just trying to
help. Tell them. Brett looked at her. He
looked at her as if he was seeing her
for the first time. The noise, the
static, the years of her overwhelming
signal finally fell away.
You said gasp loser, he said. His voice

different kind of silence than I had
ever recorded. It wasn't the absence of
sound. It was the presence of truth. On
the kitchen floor, Brett continued his
voice breaking. My father was dying. And
you said, "Gasp, loser, and I I didn't."
He covered his face with his hands. I
did not do anything. That was the sound,
the signal I had been listening for all
along. My son's voice breaking through
the noise. It was still there after all
this time. It was still there. Judge
Frick's ruling was swift. The petition
for guardianship was denied with
prejudice. The matter of financial
exploitation was referred to adult
protective services for immediate
investigation. And Deanna's statements
regarding Earl Langston were referred to
the VO County Prosecutor's Office for
review. It was over. The courtroom
emptied out the shuffling footsteps
echoing on the marble floors. Deanna was
gone. Her lawyer had hustled her out a
side door. Her heels had clicked fast on
the marble, a retreating frequency, the
amplitude diminishing with every step.

APS filing and coordinate with VGO
County. You go home, Norm. You're home.

behind me. She put a hand on my
shoulder, a steady, warm pressure. I
looked across the empty courtroom. Brett
was still there. He was standing alone
in the aisle, 30 ft of polished marble
between a father and his son. He hadn't
moved. I walked toward him. I walked
slowly, not because my heart was weak,
but because some distances must be
crossed with care. I stopped 5 ft away.

ragged. 22 breaths per minute. Panic
rate. Dad, he whispered. I I did not
know. I know. I said she told me you
were. She said I know what she said. On
the floor, he choked out the words. You
were on the floor and I just His voice
fragmented, breaking into frequencies of
grief I had never cataloged because they
were too close to my own. How do you
even look at me? I took one more step. I
was close enough now to see the shame in
his eyes. Because I have spent 67 years
listening, I said, and right now I'm
hearing my son for the first time in 2
years. He broke then, not a loud
dramatic collapse. It was a quiet
folding inward, his shoulders slumping,
his head dropping. The sound he made was
raw, the sound of a foundation crumbling
from the inside. I reached out and put
my hand on his head, my fingers in his
hair, the way I used to when he was a
boy, and afraid of thunderstorms. I just
held him. It was not forgiveness. Not
yet. Forgiveness is a frequency that
takes time to tune, but it was presence.
The presence of a father who hears his
son even when the son has nothing left
to say. Later on the courthouse steps,
the February air felt clean on my face.
There was no vanilla in it. No body
spray, just the smell of Indiana winter.
Will's car was waiting at the curb.
Brett walked to his own car alone. He
would go home to an empty house. The
realignment of our lives had already
begun. I stood on the top step and
looked out over Lafayette. In the
distance, I could see the red blinking
light of the WLFY radio tower. my old
station, still broadcasting, still
sending signals out into the air,
waiting for someone to listen. I reached
into my coat pocket. I pulled out the
hearing aids. I held them in the palm of
my hand, the small plastic shells
looking insignificant against the lines
of my skin. I looked at them for a long
moment. Then I closed my hand around
them and slipped them back into my
pocket, not into my ears. The air was
cold. The morning was quiet, and for the
first time in a very long time, I didn't
need any amplification to hear the world
clearly. Norm's story reminds us of a
powerful truth. In every family, there
are frequencies we learn to tune out the
quiet person in the corner, the sigh
that says more than words ever could. We
treat them like background noise,
forgetting that the quietest people are
often the most observant. The most
dangerous truths are not shouted. They
are whispered when someone is sure you
cannot hear. It makes you wonder who is
the quietest person in your family and
what truths do you think they have
silently collected over the years. Have
you ever had that chilling moment when
you caught the truth in a casual remark
because someone underestimated what you
could hear? Tell us your story. Because
as Norm proved, sometimes the greatest
power isn't in speaking but in finally
making others listen.

videos.description:
This is a vintage OBP video.  I'm putting it up here because it is the video's anniversary!  (And the statute of limitations have run their course). 

____________Paste from Vimeo______________

John found a J3 he wanted to buy. I'm not sure how but he found it. He has a knack for it. It was about 25 miles from Colorado Springs and belonged to a woman named Donetta. Donetta's real story can not be done justice here. Only she can tell that story.
The plane was her loving late husband Gary's yellow Cub. He used to woo her with it back in the seventies, buzzing low and professing his love to her over the sound of the 65 horse Continental engine. He was taken from her before his time should have been up, and with a vengeance she was going to see to it that his Cub which had not been flown since the mid eighties was restored. It was not an easy journey for Donetta or for the plane. It was finally sort of completed and granted airworthiness recently and flown 10 miles to her house where she mowed that sparse, western "grass" on the hill behind the unique home she and her late husband built.
John, Bushy and I drove from Ohio to Colorado to pick up the plane. We made it there at 9PM --about 30 hours after we began the journey. She greeted us with the best chicken noodle soup I've had and an impressive stack of log books from the antique plane. She furnished us with grand personal stories and the weather report, which seemed rather grim--in a windy way.
We admired the plane with some flash lights and slept like babies (except for Bushy who slept more like a DJ--making record scratching sounds all night with his sleeping bag and air mattress. He would later refine his DJ sound-scapes with more organic sounds when he became infested with a cold on the way back).
The only thing that can beat Donetta's soup is her 5 course breakfast. While she made that we went over the plane and questioned the last mechanic's license. We were about to fly across the country in a craft with a couple missing cotter pins on attach points of the wing. hmmmmmmm. There's nothing quite like a thorough pre-flight.
We made a couple quick mods here and there and accepted the latest signatures as fact, because, let's face it, signatures make airplanes fly.
The adventure ahead and the emotional goodbye for Donetta was a strange concoction. It seemed like a scattered dream but I will remember it forever (especially since there was a camera--thanks camera, i love you).
John Graham taxied that little plane up the hill and used almost all of the runway against the wind's wishes.
The rest of the adventure is left to the imagination.
